Issues.Title: Need reference Template Variable To FormControl
Issues.Body:
- I am working with large and complex Nested Reactive Form. In many case, i want to get reference from Template Variable to Form Control to pass to Function Parametter. But Angular now do not support it. For Example:

test.component.html

<input formControlName="testControl" #test="testControl" />

I knew that, i can pass form FormControlGroup or #test="ngForm" or #test="ngModel" but it's not good in this case. I want to reference to specify FormControl.

Thank you. Many people in my team and in the world also need that Feature. ^^
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Need reference Template Variable To FormControl" (#35403)

Issues.Title: Change detection regression in ivy
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package ivy in 9.0.1 ### Is this a regression? Fails to update templateRef in ivy, but works in VE. ### Description TemplateRef inside a dynamic component created by Ag-Grid is not updated in Ivy. All my components are OnPush, and I'm using cdr.detectChanges() on a parent of ag-Grid Angular component. I tried to simplify the issue without using ag-grid but couldn't reproduce it. Relevant code: https://github.com/ag-grid/ag-grid/blob/master/community-modules/angular/src/angularFrameworkComponentWrapper.ts#L54 https://github.com/ag-grid/ag-grid/blob/master/community-modules/angular/src/angularFrameworkComponentWrapper.ts#L72 https://github.com/ag-grid/ag-grid/blob/master/enterprise-modules/status-bar/src/statusBar/statusBar.ts#L83 ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction https://github.com/antoinebrault/angular-ivy-cdr (couldn't get stackblitz to work with ag-grid) ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:**

Issues.Title: IVY Error NG6002: Appears in the NgModule.imports of AppModule, but could not be resolved to an NgModule class
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package The issue might be related to package [ng-packagr](https://github.com/ng-packagr/ng-packagr) ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: 8.2.14 ### Description Possible duplicate of #35331, #34983, #35255, and #30972, but I'm including a minimal reproduction repo. Building with IVY throws the following error (see the Exception or Error section) ![StackBlitz Error](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1767135/74392714-e0448a00-4dbc-11ea-8bd8-a938995b0394.png) Our real app, which uses a shared module, throws a slightly different error: ![Concise Error](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1767135/74392793-1a159080-4dbd-11ea-9cc8-ba873769fefd.png) Running the ng-packagr postinstall script adds "__ivy_ngcc__" folders to some of our other dependencies, but does not touch the [angular2-highcharts](https://github.com/gevgeny/angular2-highcharts) library. The library does not use the Angular Package Format, which might be part of the problem, but I'm not the library's author and have never built an ES6/angular library myself, so I'm just guessing at a potential fix. Unfortunately, the library is no longer maintained, but it is one of our app's core/major dependencies. I also attempted to rebuild the library from the source files after adding the following to the library's package.json file: 

"postinstall": "ngcc --properties es2015 browser module main --first-only --create-ivy-entry-points",
"ngPackage": {
  "lib": {
    "entryFile": "index.d.ts"
  }
},
But this produces the following error: ![Error](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1767135/74393168-20583c80-4dbe-11ea-8024-d00a1ff2c4cc.png) There is no "files" array provided in the library's package.json file, so I'm not sure what the error is referring to. I fixed all Angular 9-related issues prior to re-building the library, so I assume it has to do with the way it's packaged or how it exports the modules/components. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction StackBlitz https://angular-ivy-cant-be-resolved.stackblitz.io GitHub repo in case StackBlitz isn't working: https://github.com/stevethemacguy/angular-ivy-cant-be-resolved-bug Steps to Reproduce 1. Download or clone the repo 2. npm install 3. ng build (or ng serve) Expected behavior: IVY builds the app Actual behavior: IVY displays an error. ## üî• Exception or Error 
ERROR in node_modules/angular2-highcharts/dist/index.d.ts:8:22 - error NG6002: Appears in the NgModule.imports of AppModule, but could not be resolved to an NgModule class

8 export declare class ChartModule {
## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** 
Angular CLI: 9.0.2
Node: 10.15.3
OS: darwin x64

Angular: 9.0.1
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic
... router
Ivy Workspace: Yes

-----------------------------------------------------------

@schematics/update                0.900.2

typescript                        3.7.5
webpack                           4.41.2
**Anything else relevant?** After disabling IVY, our real app successfully builds in AOT (prod mode) using Angular 9.0.1, so the issue seems to be an Angular regression that is un-related to our app (except for the [angular2-highcharts](https://github.com/gevgeny/angular2-highcharts) dependency). Our app uses a custom angular/webpack build. It does not use Angular CLI.

Issues.Title: ci: reenable draft mode conditioning for pullapprove
Issues.Body:
Previously there was a regression in PullApprove which preventing draft mode
from being respected correctly for PullApprove processing.  This regression
has been remedied and we should be able to once again respect draft mode for
PRs.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "ci: reenable draft mode conditioning for pullapprove" (#35396)

Issues.Title: Unit Tests - Overriding large modules slows down createComponent
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package @angular/core/testing ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: .... This is a regression from: https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/33787 https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/33735 ### Description A clear and concise description of the problem... The angular style guide recommends using shared modules for re-usable features. https://angular.io/guide/styleguide#shared-feature-module As a result, in our production app, we have very large shared modules containing many components, pipes, services, directives, common imports for angular material, etc. When testing one of our feature component outside the shared module, it takes 8-9 seconds to create the component when we use overrideModule. Our use case is as follows. - Lazy Loaded Module -- Module 1 -- Module 2 - imports module 1, shared module, declares feature component, but doesn't export it --- Feature Component Being Tested - spec file imports module 2, overrides module 2 to export feature component - Shared Modules -- contains lots of components, service, pipes, etc... Our spec file contains 21 unit tests and these are the times for each test being run. This is logging just the createComponent function. ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24984762/74381599-e0399e00-4e3f-11ea-8ec3-dc314b133492.png) This is performance tab for just 1 unit test. ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24984762/74381639-f5aec800-4e3f-11ea-8b2e-438b2aa68f67.png) ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction We are unable to share our production application, however I have a minimal reproduction, the scope is smaller, but still represents the slow down factor even for a small shared module. The order of the tests being run and the component caches affects the times, but this shows with both the fast test running first and the slow test running first. ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24984762/74381294-4671f100-4e3f-11ea-8235-86be54738b44.png) ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24984762/74381315-4ffb5900-4e3f-11ea-8c1f-34e7aeed5e55.png) https://github.com/ChristopherKiss/angular-unit-test-repo * run `npm i` * run `ng test` * open console and note the timings * refresh to run tests a few times For reference the tests are being run from `src/app/test/test/test.component.spec.ts` ## üî• Exception or Error

Issues.Title: sanitizeHTML incorrectly strips <tr> (and more tags) in IE, FF, Edge
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package `@angular/core` ### Is this a regression? I cannot tell. ### Description `sanitizeHtml` (or binding to `[innerHtml]`) strips out `` or other table related tags in Firefox, Internet Explorer, Edge. But working in Chrome. It can be demonstrated by following: ```
``` Seems the problem lies in `getInertBodyElement_DOMParser` which tries to parse the content into DOM, but directly adds the content into `body`, while adding `` into body is invalid in some browsers, resulting in stripping the elements. Additionaly, no warning about stripped content is produced, because this happens before calling the `sanitizer` itself in `_sanitizeHtml` ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction [https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-qbswrh?file=src%2Fapp%2Fapp.component.html](https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-qbswrh?file=src%2Fapp%2Fapp.component.html) Open in Firefox. ```

Issues.Title: docs: Add documentation about the CLI failing
Issues.Body:
docs(Lazy-loading feature module): Improve documentation for CLI lazy module generation errors 

The CLI seems to trow very non-descriptive errors when it can't generate lazy modules specifically over normal non-lazy loaded modules. I think having documentation about common modules, multiple imports in sub-trees is going to save a lot of time. I think the problem is not well documented, and if people can't get lazy loading to work, it may persuade more people to not choose Angular.

Issues.Title: Input with name "class" and host binding for class have a different behaviour in ng8 and ng9
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report

### Affected Package
The issue is caused by package @angular/core


### Is this a regression?
Yes, in angular before version 9 this bug was not presented.
Before ng9 @Input properties don't be affected with host.class.


### Description

```
@Component({
  ...
  host: { class: 'attributes' },
})
export class SomeComponent {
  @Input('class')
  public klass: string;
}
```

In angular before ng9 for pice of code above we had a bit different behaviour.

In case, when we use our component like `<some-component class="test"></some-component>` for angular 8, after ngOnInit, we had only "test" in "klass" variable. But for angular 9 we have concatenated input property with host.class and now it equals klass === "attributes test" for example above.

It looks strange and logically at the same time. Possibly, there is feature of Ivy, but I want to clarify and be sure that its not a bug of Ivy and ng9.

My examples for reproduction is totally the same with only one thing different - angular version.

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction
For angular version 8 and early: https://ng-run.com/edit/urRUMm5njGb9EAOsgtuh

For angular version 9: https://ng-run.com/edit/y5YZ2sHv9uC0N900mHAz

## üî• Exception or Error
I expect that it works like before. So, @Input('class') doesn't affected with host.class

## üåç  Your Environment

**Angular Version:**

angular 8.2.14 and angular 9.0
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Input with name "class" and host binding for class have a different behaviour in ng8 and ng9" (#35383)

Issues.Title: Using the CommonModule for NgClass inside an Angular elements setup using Ivy with renderComponent yields an "Uncaught Error: Cannot inject Renderer2 when the application uses Renderer3!"
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package The issue is probably caused by package @angular/common ### Is this a regression? This is an entirely new problem ### Description A clear and concise description of the problem... I was trying to migrate an existing Angular Web Component to a new setup with Ivy using the …µrenderComponent function. While for the most part it worked, the usage of `ngClass` completely breaks the custom element. I suppose it comes from this [line](https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/packages/common/src/directives/ng_class.ts#L49), but I can be very wrong. If I understand correctly, `NgClass` uses the `Renderer2` class for setting and removing class names, but somehow in Ivy Renderer2 should not be used (or whatever). So this breaks existing functionality. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction [This repository](https://github.com/Armenvardanyan95/ng-class-issue-reproduction) contains a minimal reproduction of the issue. It is very straightforward: It contains an Angular component, a minimal web component setup that just renders the Angular component using the …µrenderComponent function, and a module that imports the Angular CommonModule. The import works fine. Other directives from the module like NgForOf seem to work fine, and only NgClass breaks, as far as I have seen. The build finishes without exceptions. ## üî• Exception during runtime: 

core.js:15511 Uncaught Error: Cannot inject Renderer2 when the application uses Renderer3!
    at getOrCreateRenderer2 (core.js:15511)
    at injectRenderer2 (core.js:15527)
    at push../node_modules/@angular/core/__ivy_ngcc__/fesm2015/core.js.Renderer2.__NG_ELEMENT_ID__ (core.js:27320)
    at getOrCreateInjectable (core.js:5361)
    at Module.…µ…µdirectiveInject (core.js:20759)
    at NodeInjectorFactory.NgClass_Factory [as factory] (common.js:3878)
    at getNodeInjectable (core.js:5598)
    at instantiateAllDirectives (core.js:12645)
    at createDirectivesInstances (core.js:11881)
    at Module.…µ…µelementStart (core.js:20943)

... common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, elements
... language-service

Issues.Title: CLI builder examples are not OS agnostic
Issues.Body:
# üìö Docs or angular.io bug report ### Description The examples of the CLI Builders in the Techniques section are highly dependent on the Linux operating system. Particularly the commands `ls` and `touch` are not recognized in the Windows environment. Since not all of us work on a Linux machine, it would be great if it could be updated to use an OS agnostic example. I would be more than happy to help with this. I have already created a CLI builder for the needs of our company that injects a script tag in the `index.html`. You can find more details [here](https://www.npmjs.com/package/ng-builder-google-maps). I think that this is a good case for a simple example on how to create a builder. Issues.Title: Cannot build custom builder that extends the build-angular with v9
Issues.Body:
Hello everyone! This is my first Angular contribution, sorry in advance for any missing details üòÑ # üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: 8.3.24 ### Description When trying to build a custom Angular builder, an error occurs telling there is an incorrect import `import("../../../build_webpack/src")` in `node_modules/@angular-devkit/build-angular/src/extract-i18n/index.d.ts:12:110`. I believe this can be fixed if the `execute` function explicitly defines the return type (https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/master/packages/angular_devkit/build_angular/src/extract-i18n/index.ts#L54), similar error happens to me sometimes when building my Angular library, Of course, going to the `index.d.ts` file in the `node_modules` and correct import with `import("@angular-devkit/build-webpack")` works. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction https://github.com/yowari/custom-builder-error ``` npm install npm run build ``` ## üî• Exception or Error 
../../node_modules/@angular-devkit/build-angular/src/extract-i18n/index.d.ts:12:110 - error TS2307: Cannot find module '../../../build_webpack/src'.

12 export declare function execute(options: ExtractI18nBuilderOptions, context: BuilderContext): Promise<import("../../../build_webpack/src").BuildResult>;
## üåç Your Environment
**Anything else relevant?**

Issues.Title: Syntax error when compiling clearInterval inside setInterval with optimization=true
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [x] build - [x] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? Unknown. ### Description Given the code: 

let name = setInterval(() => {
    clearInterval(name);
}, time);
Building or serving with optimization=true will result in a syntax error, and building or serving with optimization=false results in no such error. Changing "let" to "var" will fix the issue but I feel the functionality should be consistent with or without optimization. I speculate this issue may apply to anytime an anonymous function is used as a parameter in any function, and the anonymous function attempts to access the variable referencing the enclosing function, but I have no evidence to back that up. ## üåç Your Environment

Issues.Title: deprecated dependency: request@2.88.2
Issues.Body:
It appears that this version, which is deprecated is being pulled in by `@angular/cli` (via `universal-analytics`). I assume a bump to the latter's version will be enough to fix this?

You can see this warning when doing a fresh install of CLI@9.0.1:

```
warning @angular/cli > universal-analytics > request@2.88.2: request has been deprecated, see https://github.com/request/request/issues/3142
```

Issues.Title: Add ng xi18n support for source code strings
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request

ng xi18n should also extract strings from the source code files.

### Command (mark with an `x`)
- [ ] new
- [ ] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [x] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc

### Description
Currently xi18n extracts strings only from templates, not from .ts file. Starting from Angular 9 you can now localize source code string using $localize. However without the extraction support this feature is pretty useless.

### Describe the solution you'd like
When I run ng xi18n, it should extract strings from templates and .ts files.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Add ng xi18n support for source code strings" (#16943)

Issues.Title: feat(@angular/cli): update command should print error stack in verbose mode
Issues.Body:
Currently, the Angular CLI only prints the erorr message if a migration
fails unexpectedly. This is not helpful because developers running `ng
update`
usually share the error upstream if they run into a bug. Sharing the error
upstream without a stack trace isn't helpful in most of the cases, so there
needs to be a way for developers to retrieve a more verbose error w/ stack trace.

Based on various ng-update issues, developers seem to pass the `--verbose`
flag with the assumption of getting a more _verbose_ error. This change
ensures that this works as expected.

Based on initial discussion over Slack, a better long-term solution
would be to always print the verbose stack trace to a debug/error file.
That way, the update experience is not too verbose by default, but the
intitial errors could be easily shared when an update issue is reported
upstream. This is out of scope for now though because the current goal

Issues.Title: Set default app locale without using localize flag
Issues.Body:
This looks like a regression to me in v9:

I couldn't find a way to tell the cli the default locale to inject in my app instead of the default `en-US`. The only method I found is using the `localize` flag, but enabling it changes the way the app is built and slows the process with the extra _Generating localized bundles_ phase.

Shouldn't it inject the `sourceLocale` defined in the `angular.json` the way the `--i18nLocale` flag used to worked in pre v9 versions?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Set default app locale without using localize flag" (#16950)

Issues.Title: `CdkDragDrop.previousIndex` is never being updated
Issues.Body:
It looks like `CdkDragDrop.previousIndex` is never being updated. It always reports the original index - rather than the previous - of the thing being dragged.

#### Reproduction

https://github.com/angular/components/pull/18456 reproduces this issue.
 
#### Expected Behavior

`CdkDragDrop.previousIndex` has the "before _this_ drag" index value of the thing I'm dragging, rather than the "before _any_ drags occurred" index value of the thing I'm dragging.

#### Actual Behavior

`CdkDragDrop.previousIndex` has the "before _any_ drags occurred" index value of the thing I'm dragging.

#### Environment

- Angular: HEAD (dev)
- CDK/Material: HEAD (dev)
- Browser(s): chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu):  mac, linux
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "`CdkDragDrop.previousIndex` is never being updated" (#18482)

Issues.Title: fix(material-experimental/mdc-form-field): setup typography styles for form-fields
Issues.Body:
Currently the MDC-based form-field does not have any typography styles.
MDC only sets typography styles on the inputs and textarea elements.
This won't work for our form-field since we support custom form-field
controls. To make this work, the input/textarea elements inherit the
font styles from parent elements, but we need to set up the typography
styles for the containing `mat-form-field` element.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(material-experimental/mdc-form-field): setup typography styles for form-fields" (#18480)

Issues.Title: Clarify use of non-standard "align" attribute for mat-dialog-actions
Issues.Body:
#### Documentation Feedback

Documentation suggests using the `align` attribute to align the content of `mat-dialog-actions` directives to the middle or right. However, `align` is an obsolete HTML attribute and not valid HTML5, and my IDE's static code analysis tools rightfully complain about using it. If using `align` really is the right way of doing this regardless of W3C standards, this should be clarified in the docs (and possibly be explicitly declared as a property of the `MatDialogActions` directive to make IDEs stop complaining). 

**Affected documentation page:** https://material.angular.io/components/dialog/overview
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Clarify use of non-standard "align" attribute for mat-dialog-actions" (#18479)

Issues.Title: Angular Material, Autocomplete loading indicator and showing text (no results found)
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

I need to show loading when searching for data and also show text when no record is found.
I have the following html excerpt:
```html
<input
    matInput
    [matAutocomplete]="auto"
    [formControl]="formControl"
    [formlyAttributes]="field"
    [placeholder]="to.placeholder"
    [errorStateMatcher]="errorStateMatcher"
/>

<mat-icon class="arrow-autocomplete">arrow_drop_down</mat-icon>

<mat-autocomplete
    #auto="matAutocomplete"
    [displayWith]="displayFn.bind(this)">

    <mat-option *ngIf="isLoading" class="is-loading">
        <mat-spinner diameter="25"></mat-spinner>
    </mat-option>

    <ng-container *ngIf="!isLoading">
        <mat-option *ngFor="let value of result$ | async" [value]="value">
            <ng-container *ngFor="let ky of to.filterKeys; let index = index">
                {{
                index !== to.filterKeys.length - 1
                    ? value[ky] + ' - '
                    : value[ky]
                }}
            </ng-container>
            <ng-container *ngIf="!to.filterKeys">
                {{ value }}
            </ng-container>
        </mat-option>
    </ng-container>

</mat-autocomplete>
```

Component.ts code:
```javascript
ngOnInit(): void {
        super.ngOnInit();

        this._unsubscribeAll = new Subject();
        this.isLoading = false;

        this.result$ = this.formControl.valueChanges.pipe(
            takeUntil(this._unsubscribeAll),
            debounceTime(300),
            startWith(''),
            tap(() => {
                this.isLoading = true
            }),
            switchMap(term => this.to.filter(term))
        );
    }
```

for loading, I would control it with the `tap()` method, but my problem is how to know that the request inside `switchMap(term => this.to.filter(term))` was finished, so I set the loading variable to false?

my second problem is how to show a registration message not found, when the server returns an empty array, because I am working with async.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Angular Material, Autocomplete loading indicator and showing text (no results found)" (#18478)

Issues.Title: fix(chips): only add type attribute to button remove icons
Issues.Body:
In #18095 we made it so that the chip remove button automatically adds `type="button"` so that it doesn't accidentally submit forms. It was made so that it always gets added since it was less code than adding extra checks, but the problem is that it ends up conflicting with some CSS resets. These changes make it so that we only add it for buttons.

Fixes #18464.

Issues.Title: fix(ng-update): do not throw if project does not have dependencies
Issues.Body:
The v9 hammerjs migration in some cases tries to remove `hammerjs`
from the workspace `package.json`. It always assumes that there is

project doesn't need to define this property. This change guards against

Issues.Title: Type="button" automatically set by matChipRemove directive
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1. Create a new project with a `<mat-chip-list><mat-chip>Some text<mat-icon matChipRemove>cancel</mat-icon></mat-chip></mat-chip-list>`
2. Import bootstrap
3. Start the application
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

I expect the close button to display properly, and I don't expect unrelated HTML attributes on the element.


#### Actual Behavior

The button displays with a square around it because `matChipRemove` directive applies a `type="button"` on the host element regardless of their tag name.

This renders a `<mat-icon type="button">` which has no sense nor utility, and it displays with a square around it, because of this bootstrap CSS rule:

```
[type=button], [type=reset], [type=submit], button {
    -webkit-appearance: button;
}
```

#### Environment

- Angular: 9
- CDK/Material: 9
- Browser(s): Chrome 79
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows 10

Related pull request: #18095
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Type="button" automatically set by matChipRemove directive" (#18464)

Issues.Body:

Fixes #18448.

Issues.Title: add example of a mat-table with re-orderable columns
Issues.Body:
This adds an example of how to re-order a table's columns with CDK drag drop.

This example can be seen at https://stackblitz.com/edit/mat-table-col-reorder. (I created that - it is almost 1:1) (It does not work since stackblitz doesn't have the fix for https://github.com/angular/components/issues/15948)

This has come up _numerous_ times in issues and requests:

- https://stackoverflow.com/questions/53377450/reorder-mat-table-rows-with-angular-materials-drag-and-drop
- https://github.com/angular/components/issues/13770
- https://embed.plnkr.co/DevUDv/
- https://medium.com/vendasta/wrapping-angular-material-table-styling-it-once-drag-drop-sorting-b1765c995b40
(etc)

*Note*: It looks like CdkDragDrop.previousIndex is never being updated. It always reports the original index - rather than the previous - of the thing being dragged. So, in this PR I've had to add a little mapping from CdkDragDrop.previousIndex -> name from column list -> actual previousIndex.

*Note*: This requires a very recent version of angular that has the fix for https://github.com/angular/components/issues/15948.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "add example of a mat-table with re-orderable columns" (#18456)
